commentBody:
Excellent workout, very Saturday-worthy. Gene Louise de Vera, your puzzle rocks. 

OK, now, I think I‚Äôve earned a trip to an all-you-can-eat Indian buffet, where I‚Äôll have ONE OF EVERYTHING of the veggie options, especially if they‚Äôre CURRIED. 

(Is it wrong to have these thoughts at 4am?)
Felt easier than yesterday. Biggest trip up was keeping fourbars in 32D instead of OPENARMS for a long time
Man, that was hard to get all right at the end! But yet another terrific Friday toughie turned out to actually be the *Saturday* puzzle that I like to wait until the morning to do, but what the hey.

Stunt puzzles can often pit a constructor's ambition against the solvers' patience, but I found today's to be quite enjoyable with the natural clueing and fill, and the wide open spaces to lob (and miss) a few Hail Mary answers. Congrats on the feat Gene!
That was amazing. Beautiful grid, and 48 across is absolutely true.

54A: [Weapon that killed Medusa, in myth]

Is there a weapon that killed Medusa outside of myth?

Today's 48A begs the question:

Can you have a revealer without a theme?

This puzzle offered me an enjoyable mix of instantaneous fill (eg, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs GARY, Indiana, obviously‚Äù and EDIT IN) and real head-scratchers (MIEN? RILL? THORA? LATTO? and my favorite, CORPORATE GREED).

‚ÄîBut this clearly reflects that I‚Äôm married to a video editor and we lived for years in Chicago, and that I‚Äôm not whatever it is that knows those other words üòÇ

This one fought me every inch of the way and only gave up its secrets grudgingly.  I‚Äôm a conservative solver who likes to be very confident before I enter an answer, but tonight I had to take a lot more fliers than I usually do, sometimes with poor results.  I was so desperate that I tried ORIGINALSINS for things that can be forgiven, even though it made no sense as original sin is a singular concept, and that long wrong down proved unhelpful.  Eventually I broke through with FASHIONICONS and BEARTHATINMIND.  there were many lovely, off kilter clues, my favorite of which was school viewing for SNORKELING.  A fitting and much appreciated Saturday challenge for me.

When I read the clue for 27A, I instantly thought of the title of Paul Simon‚Äôs 1965 song, ‚ÄúA Simple Desultory Philippic (or How I Was Robert McNamara'd into Submission).‚Äù It showed up on Simon and Garfunkel‚Äôs third album. I was in the seventh grade and learning to play guitar. I was just about to be old enough to understand much of Paul‚Äôs sarcastic TIRADE, and I find little phrases from that song popping into my head 60 years later. 

Funny how the memory works.
CORPORATE GREED, STUDENT LOANS forgiven, wanting to use Kennedy and Obama as FASHION ICONS? No prizes for guessing the politics of this particular constructor.
Fun, breezy, and very impressive. Perfect Saturday.
Restaurant order being ‚Äúhave‚Äù was something I had trouble wrapping my mind about but I guess it‚Äôs the order, as in what you‚Äôll have vs what you‚Äôll order from the server.

Reminds me of an old joke:

What did the Dalai Lama say to the hit dog vendor?

That was pretty fun.  Very unlike that other recent constructor's "stunt" puzzle that, from what little I recall, was a failure in every respect as an actual puzzle.

This one is a nice job, thanks.

Don't get me wrong - I still care not at ALL that he managed to have different length answers.  That seems... entirely unremarkable really? But if it makes him happy and ALSO presents a satisfying experience for us, fine.

I suppose 1 and 2 letter answers must be out of the question...  But the word "everything" seemed a little pyrrhic or something like that.

Ok difficulty this was only moderately hard to me, finishing pretty quickly.

What‚Äôs with the giant T in the center of the grid?

I sure hope you-know-who has gotten to Will Shortz

Oh fun indeed. What a brilliant accomplishment, answers ranging in length from 3 to 15 squares, that's what I'm talking about when we look for possible POYs (Puzzle of the Year). Surely one like this has to be among the best of the year, at least in the Sheer Chutzpah category!

Kind of like a pangram for a puzzle using every letter in the alphabet...Omniverbalongitudo? (Words of every length?)

(As in my previous post on THE GRIDDIES (Award for POY), please post as REPLIIES to this any nominations from 2025 for Puzzle of the Year. All you need to put down is date of puzzle and name of constructor. All are welcome!)

I like the bad restaurant experience reported in this puzzle; surely ordering the curried crab some food additive had turned hot pink might have caused the bad breath that led your date to wrinkle her nose and gasp, "Aw man!" The evening got even worse back at the hotel when all the bidets in the building began flooding (corporate greed had compelled management to not do their regular order of Drano). When she emerged from the bathroom looking like she'd been snorkeling, she did not exactly greet you with open arms, and something in her mien told you a tirade was coming. She'd had it. 

Well, it's only a date.  Bear that in mind for next time: take her to your old favorite, Thora's Ragin' Cajun Hoagies in Acton, up Rt. 126 from Natick! No student loans needed, no fashion icons to be seen. "Lettuce tomato onion?" 

"Yeah. One of everything!"

Really enjoyed this one. All three of the down clues on the right hand side of the puzzle eluded me until near the end, but I smiled when I got them. My only slight gripe is with 9 down which feels grammatically‚Ä¶ off?

One of those aha! puzzles, but it's another uh uh,  continually evolving until you see what it really is.  I kept trying to figure out how to get a whale into 17D, that sort of thing.  It was mano a mano, top to bottom, and fun all the way.  If there were any oreos, I didn't see them.

A terrific puzzle, Gene Louise, and I'm EAGER for another.

I really enjoyed this one. So many clever clues that both furrowed my brow and made me smile. (‚ÄúSchool viewing‚Äù was a favorite.) I also came >thisclose< to completing my first Saturday puzzle without a single lookup, but with a block of unknowns in the lower right (and an error in PiCO), I eventually gave in and learned about YAW. The rest fell in place after that. Oh, well. I‚Äôm still proud of myself.
It wasn't easy, but rather a nice work out.  I had ow man and lotto, but it was aw man and latto.

"Here's the hoagie you wanted."
"You're my hero!"

(This pun is sub-par.)

This was about as hard as a Saturday can be without my needing to look stuff up. I made very slow progress at first but I kept at it and managed to fill the grid without outside help.

Well, almost. When I entered the final letter at the crossing of L(A)TTO and (A)WMAN (not my favorite kind of cross in an otherwise fine puzzle) I got the dreaded "So close" popup... The grid looked fine though. I ended up consulting the answer key. My error was CORPORATE [c]REED crossing with EC[c]. I'm hopeless with medical abbreviations, especially in English. The Polish equivalent is EKG. And corporate creed was not non5en5ical, which prevented me from spotting the error.

I liked the clueing in this puzzle. It was misleading but in a cool way. The trivia was also kept to a minimum, which is always welcome (albeit I've never heard of that rapper). I also got the impression there was great variety in the entries, which made the puzzle feel fresh.

I found some entries arcane because I'm Polish. For example, our heating systems never involve OIL TANKS. Most of us in cities get our heat from heating plants, and outside cities people use either electricity or gas for heating. Sadly, coal is also still in use, albeit to a much lesser extent than only a decade or two ago.
That was a good Saturday. As I often find them, really difficult to start but get a foot in the door and you‚Äôre off!
Extremely fun puzzle - thanks for making it!
Bravo. Really nice puzzle, long entries in a mirror pattern replete with bad puns. Very nice.

got 1A (Possible turnoff on a first date) immediately and had the sinking thought:  its gonna be another gimme puzzle in this week of gimmes.
40 minutes later and toweling off my cerebral hemispheres (metaphorically, not neurosurgically) i recline very much corrected.
not even a nuance of a niggle here.
17D (School viewing) really floated my boat.
superb saturday workout.
Whew!  Finished without lookups. Tough, but fair.

and ezersky again for the mini win.
fiendishly clever use of "straight" and "sets."
cannot be easy in such a tight space.
mini of the year.

LATTO was a gimme. After FASHION ICONS, shift shape had me thinking dress not MORPH. SNORKELING made me smile, anything to do with sea life will. Had DiNGS for DONGs. HOT PINK pride triangle makes an important appearance. SEA DOVES are the absolute cutest! 

I‚Äôm EAGER for more, give me ONE OF EVERYTHING.

Annnnnnnnnd, go Gunners!

Loved it. This is the kind of puzzle that's very satisfying. Only a couple of answers on the first pass but, without too much trivia, everything is work-outable until it all just sort of falls into place. Bravo!
Difficult, fabulous, and fair.  Really enjoyed it once I realized it wasn't going to slam me if I was just patient.

When I began last night, it seemed like the Tale of Two Puzzles.  If you drew a diagonal line from the SW corner to the NE corner, I had everything filled above the line, and nothing filled below the line. I was able to complete the puzzle when I resumed this morning.

The puzzle seemed harder than my 28% below average time would indicate.

Tremendous puzzle. I confess the clever trick passed me by (as I‚Äôm sure is the case for most solvers) and I‚Äôm glad it didn‚Äôt detract from the overall end result. What really fixed me was the TIARA. In my mind, a tiara is a delicate, graceful, bejewelled, glittering, feminine accessory, normally twinned with an artfully admirable hair arrangement. It commands you to admire the wearer‚Äôs rank and beauty, and it makes an unmissable declaration of entitlement, while coyly pretending to be understated because - crucially - it is not a crown. Why on earth would a Pope be wearing one of those? Well, today I learned of the ‚Äúpapal tiara‚Äù, last used by Paul VI. It‚Äôs nothing delicate or understated. It‚Äôs more like an oil drum made of gold, or an inflated Christmas cake. Actually, its tiered structure reminds me of the Tower of Babel. What a monstrosity! No wonder it was abandoned. And how fitting, perhaps, that it now lives in Washington DC. (I hope a certain resident of that town never finds out about it - I think it would complete his ‚Äúlook‚Äù, not to mention his ego!) For a picture of the tiara: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Papal_tiara
Challenging but satisfying!

Definitely a constructor's grid, but a fun puzzle to fill also. When I got to the revealer at 48A, I stopped for a bit and thought about how unusual it is to have only one spanning entry in a puzzle. I wondered about the shape for a bit, and noticed the mirror symmetry. But that was as close as I got to figuring out the theme, because ONEOFEVERYTHING took some time to fill in. YAW helped.

The clues they come up with to include combos of EEL are getting pretty weird. Pot user indeed. Made me laugh.

Excellent crossword!
I got them all, no looking up, helpful crossers (eg for LATTO, TRI and THORA, never would have got them) clever cluing with the school, ECG, ESP, PALETTE,  OVA; and I knew SEN from earlier in the week. I've learnt about subs and HOAGIES - any difference between them?

Loved it.
This puzzle was Neato.
As I was finishing, I had to cue up Journey's 'Open Arms' and then right after the last letter fell it was time for Latto's 'Big Energy'. Couple a great songs!

Maybe I'm being too literal, but isn't there more than ONE OF EVERYTHING?

This was a fine puzzle, but with the exception of CURRIED CRAB, I found the long answers just a little too obvious.  I did have BEAR THis IN MIND at first, but the others just popped into my head fully formed, making this go by too quickly.

I'm not usually good at seeing the long answers so easily, so maybe this was just a wavelength thing.
This puzzle is not 15 x 15. it is 15 x 14.
My favorite pop culture moment featuring a TIARA. https://youtu.be/8i_WpYc3YI4?si=r6xCYk0qFZyWXJaL
Yellow 5 and red 40 are food colorings, which unfortunately fits, and threw me off, otherwise a very nice puzzle.

"So let it be written; so let it be done," growled Yul Brynner (Rameses II) in the 1956 film The Ten Commandments:

10. Forget the clock, the news, and check your troubles at the door.
9. Give the grid your first round efforts.
8. Trust those instincts - if it feels like it fits, fill it in!
7. Lucky you, if those initial guesses make it past your next go round.
6. Getting serious now, gotta separate the soft whir of supposition from the roar of ignorance.
5. Half-done OR half-cooked? It's all a state of mind (and white grid space).
4. Time for forgiveness - ease up on the "What was I thinking, 'food coloring!'" moment.
3. Keep trying. Every round of across and down is a chance to scratch and claw out a few letters or word.
2. Enjoy that AHA! The penny drops! That decoder ring in your head finally calibrates with the constructor.
1. Lean back, take a deep breath. You did your best. 

A fine Saturday puzle. Best of all, they'll be another one tomorrow! Happy weekend solving, everyone.
Sometimes it's just one little thing that caps off the solving experience for me. Today that is the Cry in many a horror film/RUN combo.

Saturdays have on average been somewhat kind to me in the couple of months I‚Äôve been trying to do this, so I was cautiously optimistic opening it today, even after yesterday‚Äôs disaster.  One look at the grid said it‚Äôs going to be way above my level. I jumped in anyway and quickly realised I was absolutely right, I had no chance. I‚Äôm really bad at long answers.
It does look to me like this is one you‚Äôd enjoy if you are a proper crossworder.

Whew. And Wow! Tough workout for me, but a truly amazing puzzle. One thing in particular - the down triple stacks on each side of the puzzle - those all being the longest down answers...

... everyone one of those is its FIRST appearance in any puzzle, though each of them is a reasonably familiar term or phrase. That's just amazing.  

Again - Wow. 

....

This was was right in my wheelhouse so a pretty quick one for me, but highly enjoyable. 

Latto was actually a gimme for me. She had a song that was on the radio that I took notice of as it samples 'Genius of Love'. I'm still an 80s New Wave girl.
Clearly this was the most enlightening puzzle ever.  Gene Louise De Vera made us one with everything!
Neato.

I immediately saw and greatly appreciate putting subs directly above dub. 

Amazing crossword, and wonderful clueing

Being a graphic designer, I had ‚Äúmagenta‚Äù for 19A until my slightly-more-awake brain kicked in. 31D had me mystified as I had never heard of ‚Äúsea dove‚Äù which looks nothing like a little auk. Not sure why they would call it that. This was a workout, but it‚Äôs a pretty amazing puzzle.

I'm sure there's a subset of solvers here that knew both MATINS and LATTO.

I'm not in it, though, which left me having to go ask Google...my only lookup for this puzzle.

Okay, here‚Äôs something amazing ‚Äì those triple stacks flanking the east and west?  All six of those long answers are NYT debuts, including the gorgeous BEAR THAT IN MIND, CORPORATE GREED, and GET THE MEMO.

Those six answers are all touched by ONE OF EVERYTHING, another gorgeous answer (and NYT debut).  

ONE OF EVERYTHING, as the revealer, had to be in the grid.  So those six triple-stack answers of which I speak had to accommodate that revealer‚Äôs letters.  Thus, not only did Gene manage to do that cleanly -- a very difficult task -- but he did it so gorgeously.  Absolutely amazing.

Did the grid suffer from this feat?  No, it did not.  Au contraire, it sung because of it, sung with spark and beauty.  This is not a ‚Äúclever-by-half‚Äù feat; it is pure artistry.

What a lovely Saturday, with wit and guile.  Saturday clues like [Order at a restaurant], for HAVE, where ‚Äúorder‚Äù can be a verb or noun, and whichever it is, there are still multiple answer possibilities.  I want muddy clues like this on Saturday.  I want my HAVE to HAVE to HAVE crosses.

An uber-low 62-worder so beautifully filled and satisfying to fill in.  Masterful, Gene.  An accomplishment that pays off for the solver.  I. Absolutely.  Loved. This.  Thank you!
Great puzzle, but....I want to start a petition that decrees that that any clue asking for a rapper must auto fill. Really, there must be 10,000 of them out there.
Eel pot?! How on earth did I know that one?! Sometimes the puzzle delves into some very weird crevices of the brain.  ü§£
Amazing puzzle. Loved, loved, loved it.

@Lewis ‚Äî I‚Äôm grateful for your perceptive comments.  They really help me appreciate grids like this, which for some reason are not my cup of tea.  I started grumbling at 2D and never quite got into the swing of things this morning.  

Well off to choir practice. We‚Äôre doing the Schubert Magnificat tomorrow. Rehearsing with orchestra this morning!
That was a fun solve. Two proper names gave me some trouble but in the end it was enjoyable.
Fastest Saturday solve for me, and by a longshot.

This one was tough, as tough as the $2 steaks that used to be served up in Times Square‚Äôs Childs restaurants. üòÉ My solving needs some brushing up on, as the clues seem to be a ways from my wavelength‚Ä¶On positive note the puzz had a freshness factor purely off the charts; which brings on today‚Äôs music from Emmett Rhodes. The title is ‚ÄúFresh As A Daisy.‚Äù https://youtu.be/0uHamlvvUHc?si=VAjoK9c-Ta8QYBpC

Not particularly enjoyable for me. Some of the fill was ... well, I think it speaks for itself: ARD, NOTDO, NOI, AWMAN, OHFUN, EDITIN, ACTON, LATTO, HADIT. Did I mention ARD?

The long entries were much better, but, for me, didn't compensate for the glue needed to bind them together. 

A feat of construction, I'm sure. Just not a very satisfying Saturday offering. Solved it without help in 23:23, with the A common to LATTO and AWMAN being my last entry.

Liked the simple and clever "Sound from fans" for WHIR.

Really liked this one.  When there are long answers I like to chuck in initial answers and see what sticks.  Only my initial 1 across worked out for me today.  Also, wolverines and otters, who knew ?   Well, at least I didn‚Äôt!

Thought this might be my fastest Saturday ever ‚Ä¶ then I hit a wall on the east side of this one. My brain just couldn‚Äôt come up with the answers. Oh well. There‚Äôs always next Saturday! I appreciated the amazing construction feat though. Very cool!üòé

I know I can be guilty of too much name-dropping(Thora Birch, Latto and Princess Di have all teased me about it), but I had to share that I met Medusa once.

I think. I can't be sure because I was stoned.
I really wanted 40A to be ‚Äòbreakfast‚Äô.

Okay, I'll bite:  was the proposed 12D entry USPRESIDENTS?  And what did that do to the entire West side of the puzzle?  

Is this Odd Names Day?  Now, I had a cousin THYRA, but this is my first time to see THORA as a female name.  And then LATTO (also styled "The Uknown Rapper") was a new experience.  

Hey, all you nurses, teachers, therapists and such, who were hoping for STUDENT LOANS...fergit it!  Those aren't Real Professions!  BEAR THAT IN MIND when choosing a major!

I guess I don't have much else to say.  POCO a poco....

MINI SPOILER ALERT


In today‚Äôs puzzle, two answers are the same. Is this worth writing an email about asking a refund or is it kosher.
Same Larson as Far Side?

Had a dad named Philip; immediately thought of how it means, "lover of horses," and EAGERly ACTedON that hunch and typed in, "equine" for 27 across.  AW, MAN!  Apparently, I never GOTTHEMEMO about its actual meaning.  I guess you *can* learn something new every day!  

Fun puzzle!

This was a doozie! I was thinking, wow, I am right on this constructor‚Äôs wavelength, as I filled in the entire north and west halves in a matter of minutes with only a few letters filled in. Then I hit a wall on the east and south sides that took me three times as long, making for a puzzle that was longer than my Saturday average. 

But I loved it! That satisfying feeling when you just can‚Äôt think of anything, and then letter by letter (and with a few erasures), it reveals itself. Having confidently entered LIZZO at 41D and AVOID at 25A held me up for quite a while. Once erased, things started to fall into place. My favorite was 17D, which gave me a laugh when I realized, ohhhh, *that* school!

What a perfectly crunchy challenge to kick off the weekend. Thank you, Gene Louise De Vera!
I usually don't look forward to Saturday puzzles, but this one was fun.

Dang‚Ä¶I had DING and it took a few minutes finding that. Still shaved a few minutes off and turned my puzzle in at just over 20 minutes.

That‚Äôs an impressive design. I had a lot of fun today. Thank you!

Sometimes when you see a puzzle and it looks really hard, you soon realize that it's not as hard as it looks.

Not today. Slower than my Saturday average, filled in a lot of wrong answers, but it eventually fell to sheer doggedness.

Good one!

What a fabulous Saturday challenge -- thank you for constructing such a clever and ambitious puzzle, Gene Louise!

Enjoy the weekend, everyone!

Well that was very hard for me. 

PALLETE was best. 

Spent way too long thinking they were colourings and not ADDITIVES. 

Excellent puzzle. Very few factoids just challenging clues. 

Thanks

This is, as Caitlin notes, the constructor's second Saturday, and I enjoyed the fresh long answers and the non-theme theme. But like the earlier Saturday, I found it not Saturday challenging. The constructor note shows that one example of that today is on the editors, not the constructor. Not sure about the rest. This is what I said in May: https://www.nytimes.com/shared/comment/47ofkd?rsrc=cshare&smid=url-share

Wow, wow, wow! Thank you for this challenging puzzle. I was telling a (relatively new) friend this week that I do the crossword puzzle everyday. She was surprised I could do Fridays and Saturdays. Well, it took me years to get to the point where I could do every day of the week - and now I appreciate the challenge of a puzzle like this. It's beautiful!

And the revealer reminds me of the Buddhist's pizza order: make me one with everything. 

Happy Saturday, everyone!

This was another accelerando. Started off slowly, sped up, then finished rather quickly as the downs against the left and right sides came into view.

For a long time, I was regularly coming in at about 2/3 my cumulative average each day of the week, but recently I'm consistently solving at less than 2/3 my average. Does that mean that my skill is accelerandoing? I'm dubious. 

That said, I found the fill fresh and fun and I laughed out loud at more than one of the answers. I'm off now to read about wolverines and otters. I definitely look forward to more from De Vera.
Cicero's are the apotheosis of Philippics.  They were so powerful they got him murdered.

Felt a little regionally biased. Never met anyone with an oil tank. Hoagies - those are subs? People say ‚Äútether to a hotspot‚Äù instead of ‚Äújoin a hotspot‚Äù? Never seen a recipe for curried anything - chicken curry, fish curry, mutton curry‚Ä¶.
Order at a restaurant =HAVE?
Thank you Brother Cadfael for MATINS, as I never would have gotten the rapper's name.
35:36, 24:59 faster than my average. Seems a morning solve is faster for me. Some answers come unbidden to mind. I always imagined the snake alternative had an I in there.

I finished this last night, but something was still amiss. Woke up this morning and that SE corner was not looking right. Scanned all of my acrosses until I got to the last one. aWaRD?! Wasn‚Äôt Medusa killed by a SWORD? ü§£ I had OPEN ARea for [Sign of good reception?] which gave me eATINS for [Morning prayer] Oh boy was that scrambled üòÜ Once I fixed SWORD, my final fix was OPEN ARMS which of course led me to the Journey song‚Ä¶my husband sings it as ‚Äúbroken arms‚Äù which always cracks me up ü§£ https://youtu.be/i5pUOVC50Y8?si=IGQaH8_x7IDj26b9 Thank you, Gene! And I think your clue of Kennedy and Obama for 12D was better and way more misleading as a Saturday should be!
Starting 32a with FURNACE for ‚Äúhome heating component‚Äù then using that F on 32d to go with FOURBARS for ‚Äúgood reception‚Äù really had me stuck in the corner for way too long.

What a fabulous achievement, never even considered that this was a feat. I echo Lewis‚Äô comments about the astonishment of 6 long debut entries stacked with a revealer of sorts. The grid design was eye catching. I thought the difficulty bead just about right‚ÄîI had nothing in the top half, had to work from the bottom up and enjoyed every minute of it. 
The constructor‚Äôs note about the FASHIONICON clue is telling. Why on earth wouldn‚Äôt you use his clue unless you were trying to decrease the level of difficulty? Unless you want to argue that Michelle OBAMA was no less a fashion icon than any other First Lady (certainly Jackie Kennedy is unarguable), or they didn‚Äôt want to put a political tinge on it. But I think whichever side of the aisle you are on you have to admit that she has influenced fashion more than most in a significant way, and the sly nod to feminism (not every Kennedy or Obama has to be a president!) would have been a fun misdirect.
Very impressive construction. Thanks for this great puzzle.

Beyond impressive! Congrats to the constructor!

It's always a satisfying solve when I can get something like TIRADE for Philippic with just the A. I got the left side pretty fast, and then puzzled for a while over the right. Perfect level of challenge for a Saturday. I've felt some recent end-of-week crosswords were either too hard or too easy - this is just right.
Started slow -- finished fast! That was fun!
Good puzzle. I got stuck for a while on little things, like "not mucho"
Loved the ‚Äúticker tape‚Äù clue. I think it was my first fill in and proud to say I didn‚Äôt need any crosses, although unsure whether it was ECG or EKG
CORPORATEGREED? How very New York Timesy!
I've never had so many wild guesses turn out to be right. Just on the perfect wavelength today. Love when that happens. Feels like having ESP.
Great idea and execution but it felt pretty easy for a Saturday.  Got FOOD ADDITIVES and FASHION ICONS right out of the gate and the rest was smooth sailing.
Bravo to the constructors. Very difficult and smartly done!!
unfortunately for me SEAFOODBOIL and ARTIFICIALDYES fit in 10A and 12A respectively
Wowser!! This was like getting the wildest bronco at the rodeo...what a fantastic and challenging ride! Merci Gene...verily!!!

I gathered all my artsiest-administratiest friends into an ad hoc panel, as it were, and not a single one could figure out what the possible misdirects were on that ‚ÄúBoard of creatives?‚Äù clue. 

Fun puzzle. A real NEATO bit of EDITIN.

I had to struggle to get this one.  I blame in on being on the road and outside my normal element.  

I had to think so hard I'll never get the small of bacon to go away.

And I really wanted [Sign of good reception?] to be OPENbarS.

I have trouble respecting a puzzle‚Äôs construction when it‚Äôs made up of primarily long answers like this because the ‚Äúchallenge‚Äù begins to feel artificial. When a long clue is revealed and I‚Äôm left with that ‚ÄúOh, sure, I guess‚Äù, unsatisfied feeling, we have a problem. But that‚Äôs me. Other than that I thought the cluing was all well and good for the most part. I don‚Äôt understand EELER. Glad to see so many people like this puzzle so we don‚Äôt have to hear any more moaning about how easy it was. üòú
OPENARMS is a sign of a good reception but I couldn‚Äôt help but think of ‚ÄúOpen bars,‚Äù also a sign of a good reception.
How does "one of everything" tie in with the theme of this puzzle?

Well, I sort of flew through this one. I'm so glad I'm done with the huge work project that came down to crunch time in the last couple of weeks because now I feel like my brain is more open again. Well and my time. Although now I have to catch up on all the work I didn't do while I was doing that work. Oh well! It helps that I really love my job!!

Anyhow, I would have preferred the constructor's original cluing for 12 down, Obama and Kennedy. I think it would have made it more puzzling. Although it might have also reminded us of that scandalous tan suit!! (Har! I know it really would have referred to the fabulous Michelle and Jackie.)

Isn't it funny how sometimes words just look really wrong, even though they're right? I hope that's not just me.  At 36 across, I plunked in EAGER And for some reason the second E just looked so wrong to me. I was like, that's not how you spell EAGER! It's too weird! So I changed it to an a, which looked even wronger, if you will. I actually very briefly left that box blank. Crazy!! But it happens every now and then where a word I know is right just looks crazy wrong. 

Oh well, I did get ECG right off the bat, so at least there's that. I had to get one very recently for my annual AFib check-in, so maybe that's why it was on my mind. Happily, my ticker tape was just fine! 

Methinks I'm a little too uncouth to appreciate the construction feat today, but it was a fine puzzle and I am happy he also achieved his goal.

Very late today. Was up and at church at 6AM today for the dawn Rorate Mass in Latin - very spiritual for me. Started in candlelight, but dawn came during the service.

I am going to buck the general trend and admit that I disliked this puzzle and agree with another poster that there were too many regionalisms including from across the pond where I have lived and traveled extensively. Also, multiple long answers where more than one appropriate answers may fit greatly detract from the enjoyment of solving the puzzle imho. It astounds me that every puzzle gets rave reviews when the law of averages (and reality) is that they cannot all be winners. I don't want to deny or diminish the thought and effort that goes into creating a puzzle but I am sure there are more people out there of a similar opinion but who don't want to comment or are concerned about being 'crosswordsplained' if they do. Some of the posters are clearly expert crossworders and try to be encouraging but some can be dismissive to any criticism of the puzzle and attribute it to ignorance or lack of intelligence rather than just accepting that there are other valid opinions and that some puzzles are just not that great for a significant minority (possibly a silent majority) of people. Thanks for letting me get that off my chest. [Stepping off my soapbox and resuming my crossword journey.]

8/27 Zhou Zhang ‚ÄúUps/Downs‚Äù
The top early week puzzle this year in my opinion, and second isn‚Äôt even close. It doesn‚Äôt hurt that it had a Thursday vibe and I would probably vote for it as the best on that day as well. This was a Schroedinger rebus with 8(!) themed elements that were clued so that the rebus could contain either UP or DOWN, and there was room for UPS and DOWNS clued separately as revealers. And despite all that, the rest of the fill and clues were darn good as well. A masterpiece. 

2/25 Greg Snitkin ‚ÄúNot on my Watch‚Äù
Not the splashiest theme in the world, with the ends of all the themers items that wouldn‚Äôt be on digital watches, but I really liked the sly pun of the revealer, all the theme entries were pretty fresh, and the fill was extremely well executed for a Tuesday AND was a pangram to boot.

3/5 Rebecca Goldstein ‚ÄúHaunted Mansion‚Äù
A really unusual grid design that accommodate 4 ‚Äúhaunted‚Äù rooms in a house that were all interesting and fresh, with the revealer HAUNTED MANSION stacked in the bottom; and a lot of fun accessory fill including two other long entries. Very impressive

3/11 Jared Cappel ‚ÄúAcupuncture‚Äù Again, not the splashiest theme, but 3 solid themers that all were phrases related to what you would do for ACUPUNCTURE, all in order, and the rest of the grid was good enough to be a light themeless puzzle.
